awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChEM: Coupling Earth-Abundant Metal-Ligand Cooperativity with Redox Non-Innocent Ligands for Electrochemical Carbon Dioxide Reduction
awd_abstract_narration:
In this CAREER project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Scott Daly of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Iowa is developing new methods for the electrochemical conversion of carbon dioxide.  Carbon dioxide, a by-product of fossil fuel combustion, is readily available.  Its conversion into other molecules such as carbon monoxide may lead to the development of high-density liquid fuels.  As a result, effective ways of converting carbon dioxide into other molecules are being actively pursued.  Professor Scott Daly's approach is based on the coupling of metal-ligand cooperativity with redox non-innocent ligands.   One advantage of his approach is that it does not require the use of expensive metals.   For his educational plan, Professor Scott Daly is developing the "Chemistry Platoon" - a tutoring and outreach program created to help student veterans to succeed in large-enrollment chemistry courses at the University of Iowa.  Being a military veteran, Professor Scott Daly is well positioned to make significant impacts in this endeavor.     

Redox-active tetradentate ligands containing o-phenylenediamine sub-units are capable of undergoing two sequential electron transfer events.  Professor Scott Daly is studying the coupling of this ligand-centered redox-activity with metal-ligand cooperative (MLC) binding to achieve efficient electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide with earth-abundant, first-row transition metals.   Redox-active ligands with modified donor substituents and structures are being prepared to identify ligand variations that promote electrochemical reduction of MLC-bound carbon dioxide.   Metal complexes containing redox-inactive tetradentate ligands are being used as benchmarks to elucidate the role of ligand redox chemistry in electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction via MLC binding.  Converting carbon dioxide from point combustion sources into carbon monoxide, an important feedstock for high-density liquid fuels such as methanol, may decrease our fossil fuel reliance so that carbon dioxide emissions can be reduced.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Molecular catalysts that convert CO2 into more valuable products are typically complexes containing metals bound by chemicals called ligands. Ligands are used to tune the reactivity of metal active sites where CO2 molecules undergo transformative processes, but it is known that specific ligands can themselves undergo chemical reactions and assist the metal in binding and activating CO2. This phenomenon is referred to as metal-ligand cooperativity (MLC). Additionally, it has been shown that certain ligands can participate in electron transfer reactions independently of the metal, a capability that can be harnessed to aid the metal in processes requiring electron transfer for the formation and breaking of chemical bonds.

While both metal-ligand cooperativity (a type of chemical reaction) and ligand-centered electron transfer (a type of electrochemical reaction) are well-documented, there remain questions regarding the interplay between MLC and ligand-centered electron transfer, particularly in the context of significant chemical substrates such as CO2. The goal of our work was to understand how chemical reactions at MLC-capable ligands influences their electron transfer capability. The impetus for this work was to determine how ligand-centered redox activity might be used to transform MLC-bound substrates like CO2 into more valuable chemicals and products. We proposed that combining these ligand centered reactions could provide access to CO2 catalysts with cheaper and more earth abundant metals than those typically required. 

Major research outcomes of this award were demonstration of how MLC influences the electron transfer properties of redox active ligands. We published a series of papers describing the synthesis of new redox active ligands and their complexes, and demonstrated how the ligands are capable of undergoing MLC reactions with BH3, a surrogate molecule that mimics the behavior of CO2. We showed how the properties of the complexes change in the presence and absence of MLC binding and with different metals in different redox states. We also showed how BH3 can undergo electrochemical reactions while bound in an MLC fashion, which led to separate studies on a series of related ligands for different types of catalysis with petroleum-related molecules. Finally, we demonstrated how ligand-centered redox activity and a technique known as cyclic voltammetry can be used to quantify the strength of MLC binding.

Collectively, these results expand our fundamental understanding of how ligand-centered chemical reactions influence electron transfer in metal complexes containing redox active ligands. The results suggest new strategies for how these different types of ligand-centered reactions may be combined for new catalyst development, especially with CO2. Our research yielded nine peer-reviewed publications (with several more in preparation), a book chapter, at least 28 presentations with acknowledgement of NSF support.

The principal educational outcome of this proposal was the Chemistry Platoon, an outreach project designed to assist student veterans and military affiliates enrolled in introductory chemistry courses at the University of Iowa. Interested students had the opportunity to meet with Professor Daly, a U.S. Army veteran, and student Platoon leaders. They convened twice a week throughout each semester, dedicating at least 90 minutes to discussing challenging course content and collaboratively tackling homework assignments.

A core focus of this initiative was to foster a robust peer network among veterans and affiliates who shared common experiences in military service and understood the unique challenges faced by these individuals and other veterans. The Platoon mentality, a concept familiar to all veterans, emphasized mutual support, mirroring the way military personnel are trained to assist one another.

The Chemistry Platoon has proven to be successful, providing valuable assistance to 10 - 20 student veterans and military affiliates each semester. Its success has also inspired the establishment of the Math Platoon and the Biology and Psychology Platoon. The Math Platoon was initiated by Zachary Graham, a former Chemistry Platoon student leader, in collaboration with Professor Colleen Mitchell of the University of Iowa's Mathematics department. The Biology and Psychology Platoon was initiated more recently and is currently led by Angela Richardson, a fourth-year Ph.D. candidate in the Interdisciplinary Neuroscience Program at Iowa.

In addition to helping student veterans excel in their chemistry courses, the Chemistry Platoon has also served as a conduit to actively involve veterans in research. Notably, four participants from the Chemistry Platoon went on to engage in undergraduate research within the Daly lab, contributing to the publication of two peer-reviewed papers in the American Chemical Society's journal Inorganic Chemistry.

In recognition of his efforts, Professor Daly received an Outstanding Faculty/Staff Advocate Award from students and staff in the University of Iowa Veterans Association. He was also honored as a Hawkeye Distinguished Veteran in 2018. The Chemistry Platoon has garnered recognition from numerous news organizations and has been featured on the NSF website. Notably, former Platoon Leader and founder of the Math Platoon, Zachary Graham, was selected as a Pat Tillman scholar, one of the most prestigious and competitive scholarships for student veterans.


Last Modified: 10/29/2023
Modified by: Scott R Daly
